publicationStmt.p: File created by Evolving Hands project, Newcastle University

div.ab:
Received Oct 25th 1921 By Air Mail
Baghdad. Oct 2 | 1921
Darling Father. I shall have to keep a sort of diary to you now, for with
fortnightly letters the intervals are too long. I shall be much annoyed
if they do not reach you, but we have once again had experience that
aeroplane communications have not that certainty which one might
desire. Major Young, whom you saw at Cairo, + a Mr Vernon from
Palestine were due to arrive here yesterday by air. Instead of
them we got a wireless message to say that Mr Vernon had
crashed + was badly injured. Today we hear that he is doing
well but we have not yet heard whether Major Young is still coming.
It is provoking, for there were a number of big questions of
policy + administration which have been saved up to be explained
to them that they might throw light on them to the office at
home + the secretary of state.
We send an immense amount of despatches home by every
airmail + the 14th + 30th of each month are days of
feverish finishing off of work. Added to which they are
the days when my Fortnightly Report has to be finished, so that
Sir Percy may see it in on the 15th + 1st before it goes to the
press. I am doing little less than writing a history of Mesopotamia
in fortnightly parts. I myself find it an invaluable record
but I've not heard what they think of it at home. The first
of October saw the 22nd number. Each number is
divided into the following parts: 1. Proceedings of the Council
of Ministers (as you might say Hansard compressed) 2. Public
events
opinion - all significant or propaganda or newspaper
campaigns or anything
in particular
that shows how the
currents are setting; 3. Notes on Provincial Affairs, the
actual history of the provinces, tribal unrest, irrigation,
everything that is going on. 4. Frontiers - whatever affects us
in the doings of Ibn Sa'ud in Arabia, the French in Syria,
the Kamalists in Anatolia; + the Kurds on our northern +
eastern frontiers. It's a great work, it really is. It goes
to all our provincial officers, as well as to India, Egypt, Aden,
Jaffa, Constantinople, Jerusalem, + London - Also Tehran. If

they don't know everything they ought to know about us, it's not
my fault.
Last night the King had his first dinner party - the Coxes, the
Sindersons (she is the woman whose conversation with Mrs Rosita
Forbes I reported) the C.G.S, Ja'far Sasun Eff + Yusuf Suwaidi.
The last was one of the leaders of last year 's revolt + is the
father of Naji Minister of Justice. Faisal had asked me to persuade
Sir Percy to be kind to him, to which the good Sir Percy suggested he
should be asked to dinner to meet him. I arranged the table +
placed him between Sir Percy + me. I have in no way altered
my opinion that he is a silly old windbag + every talk I have
with him confirms it. However Sir Percy + I were both very
nice to him. It was a most pleasant dinner party. They had
arranged it all very well + Faisal was a charming host. I'm
teaching the ADCs how to shift people about a little, so
that every guest may have his talk with the King. One
has to explain everything, you realize. not only whom to
ask but how to address the envelopes + how to fill up the
invitation cards which I've had printed. The letters after
people's names puzzle them dreadfully. I look forward to
their conferring on the Commander in Chief the order of
G.H.Q. Also they were immensely surprised when they found that
the letter had to be sent to the wife not to the husband.
At the end of the dinner Faisal, Sir Percy + I had a
nice three- cornered talk; it was the first time I had
assisted at their conversations with one another.
Today being Sunday Major Murray + I, Major Wilkinson (Wireless)
Major Greenhouse (in our office) + Saiyid Husain Afnan went
out to Fahamah to shoot. It wasn't very successful as a
shoot because it was far too hot - it happened to be a
very still close day. After beating through the scrub at the
edge of the palm gardens we all wandered back to a delicious
untenanted house where we often picnic + spent the middle of

the day in a deep verandah looking onto a shady orange grove.
I had brought out lunch + we were a very well - assorted party
most
so that it was
but
agreeable. But the temp. must have
been well up to 100 again.
Oct. 9. On Monday the C in C took the King, Ja'far Pasha + me
for a picnic - that was the party, with the addition of a couple of
a.d.c.s. We started by trolley on the railway at 7 + went up
to the Jabal Hamrin, where we arrived about 11. We ran that up
the Diyalah gorge through the little Hamrin hills - I had never
seen it before because the road doesn't follow the river + when
one goes by train one passes through it at night. That's when
you didn't see it when we went up to Khaniqin. We came back
to the opening of the gorge + there lunched under the shadow of a
rock. At this point the Ruz Canal takes off from the
Diyalah + a little higher up is the Khalis canal
canals
head. These two with two lower down make the fortune
of the Diyaluh division which is one of the most fertile +
profitable in the Iraq, with its orange + date gardens
+ acres + acres of barley - you remember the Naqib's
gardens above Ba'qubah? They are on the Khurasan,
the canal below the Ruz. The Khalis + Ruz have good
stony head works (built by us) so that the water is properly
controlled. We have hitherto kept a company at the Ruz
head but the day after we were there it was to be
withdrawn + replaced by Levies - we have no troops
now on the Diyalah. We had heavy fighting at the mouth of
the Diyalah Gorge in 1917 + there is a monument on the
hilltops on either side of the river to commemorate the
men of (I think) the 16th + 17th Brigades who fell here.
It was an extremely ill - managed affair on our part, I
believe.
But we did not call that to mind. The dead slept on the
hilltop, the river, very blue + clear in its summer slenderness

dawdled down the gorge into the wide dusty plain, + the Ruz slipped
out from its side, a deep and narrow stream, hurrying away to do
its appointed work in the fields + gardens below. Ja'far chatted,
ponderously simple + gentle - mannered with the general +
Faisal talked eagerly to me about how we would make
the women of Baghdad play their part in the 'Iraq state.
It was pleasant + cool sitting under the rock but I'm
free to confess that it was very hot indeed coming back in
the trolley in the afternoon. We took refuge in the station
master's office at Ba'qubah where the General's servant
made tea for us, stopped to photograph the great
bridge over the Diyalah - the only real bridge in the
country- + got home at dusk. A most satisfactory
day + everyone pleased.
But next day two very tiresome things happened. In the
first place the post brought me the unspeakable article in
the New York Herald. One ought to be able to give writers
of such impertinent balderdash 6 months with hard
labour. I have carefully concealed it from all eyes.
The second was a letter from Mr Nalder saying he
could not put me up when Faisal came to Mosul. I don't
think I have been so much disappointed for quite a long
time. I wanted to see in Mosulis, with whom I am
great friends, making their fine reception for the King, +
I wanted to write about it, about the old old Arab
families up there + the Kurds + the rest. But, most of
all, we are all a trifle anxious about the visit.
Mosul is very near the frontier and an agent of Mustafa
Kamal's with a revolver or a bomb - well he could
do a great deal of harm. The more of us who are round
Faisal the better, + if I may say so, I'm as good as any
because there would be such a great deal of chat if anything

happened to me. [Half the big families in Mosul would have
take me in if I had asked them for hospitality, but I
gathered between the lines of Mr Nalder's letter that he
did not want me to come, which makes me feel very sore.
He isn't very popular - Faisal does not like him at all -
I have backed him + defended him for all I'm worth
believing him to be one of our best officers - as he is.
There! I'm unburdening my soul, which is never very
wise; but the truth is I am hurt, angry + surprised.
Faisal left at dawn this morning. I went to tea with him on
Friday to say goodbye. He + Rustam + I had a tremendous
talk about how to create + foster the spirit of nationalism
here which we all feel to be so much lacking. We have you see,
the awkward + dangerous element of Turkish propaganda to
deal with. I'm persuaded that it's only a question of time.
We are now 6 weeks old + we're remarkably lusty;
wait till the Arab, or let me say the 'Iraqi government,
has been in existence a year + people will begin not
only to believe in it, but to be proud of being 'Iraqis. But
consciousness
Faisal, with his extraordinarily vivid
??
of
national existence, wants everyone to be as whole-hearted
as himself. That will never quite happen; not all
men can be torch bearers; but we will light their
little candles from his flame, the little candles of self-
interest + self - satisfaction + the rest till there is a
reasonable + sufficient illumination. And thank God for
the flame.
Peace with the Kamalists would very greatly diminish.
our difficulties, for they are trying as hard as they can
to blow our twinkling candles out.
Last night I dined with the Military College - our
local Sandhurst, opened last July. They have already
furbished up + turned out a batch of officers sufficient

for the 1st battalion of 'Iraq infantry which takes over
Hillah + the Barrage this week. The second battalion is now
being formed at Kadhimain - not so bad, is it? They are
crude, of course, but the officers are nearly all ex-soldiers
+ what they have at the outset to learn is to drop their
Turco-German tradition + get hold of an Anglo-Arab.
But they are doing it + the first batch of 27 is I'm
told quite good.
The dinner party consisted of 100 officer students, the
Arab + British officers who run the school, a few Baghdad
notables (Abdul Majid Shawi among them) one or two
British civil officers (Major Murray + one other) + me.
Oh yes + British + Arab staff officers. I sat
between Major Eadie + the Director of the School, a
capital little man called Ahmad Haqqi Beg. And
after dinner I called to Shakir Beg who is an
instructor
on their staff + Sami Beg, Colonel of the
2nd 'Iraq Infantry. Very nice people + I enjoyed
it very much. Now they have the real thing
carrying
in them, they are
??
more than candles
Ahmad Haqqi had dined with me during the
week. I had Fakhri Jamil also + 'Abdul Majid
Shawi, + the new Minister of Health, Dr Hanna
Khaiyat, + a Mosuli, one of the notables, who
happened to be in Baghdad. The dinner was a
trifle sticky because Fakhri, as far as his good
manners would permit him, was inclined to snub
Ahmad Haqqi. Fakhri takes unkindly to the Arab
army; he would much prefer the British army +
feels rather ruffled at the refusal of the British
tax-payer to maintain it here. After dinner in the

garden, however, they all talked at once and I sat by +
listened, much entertained.
I rode with Ja'far on Friday morning. Ja'far's not a
very active rider, but we jog sedately along and talk. On
our way home we went in to see the widow + daughters of
Muhammad Pasha Daghistani- I don't suppose
you'll remember, but I had a terrific business last
year, getting their wastrel of a brother, Daud, to give the
women their fair share of the property. It was one of
these girls that 'Ali Sulaiman wanted to marry - I
think I told you. They are the prettiest, most charming
creatures, Circassians. Ja'far is their foster brother
which in Islam, is like being a real brother. That's
how he can see them. They are all devoted to him.
Mr Norman has passed through. He has been recalled
from Tehran, that grave of reputations. I don't suppose he
could have done much better than he did. You can't do
anything in Persia if you've got no money behind you
+ we can't be expected to send money there. But Lord Curzon
is furious with him + his sentiments are warmly
reciprocated by Mr Norman! Percy Lorraine succeeds
him + has an impossible task to face.
Last mail brought me Mother's letters of Aug 31 + Sep 6
with the delightful account of Frances, + your letters of
the 31st, + 7th all about Paris, incidentally. You
were the first, weren't you! Darling Father. But
what a tale about you catching on the carpet +
falling down! It seems to me most amazing that after
a tumble like that, + your poor finger + all you
recovered with much celerity. I can only tell you it takes
Marie weeks to recover when she falls off a pony!

Marie, by the way, is very tiresome with the Arab servants.
She does nothing but quarrel with them, like the underbred
little minx that she is. She nearly had, quite had,
hysterics the other day + gave me notice. I told her
she might go and welcome ( which wasn't wholly true)
but she doesnt really want to go at all. I don't think
I shall bring her back with me again, if I can find
someone else. Nevertheless she is very useful to me personally.
By the way you've said nothing about the death of Rosalind
Lady Carlisle - if only it had happened 20 years ago!
I do wonder what her will is like - as perverse as she was?
Oct. 13 There's nothing further to record except the arrival of a letter
from you dated Sep. 14 containing your delightful description of Frances.
I am very sorry they have decided to go to S. Africa but I don't
feel in a position to criticize since my "call" has taken me
equally far away. But I must tell you that I myself do often
wonder whether right to stay. One is so much inclined to
exaggerate one's own importance + if I went no doubt the Arab
Kingdom would wag along, however much I may think it
wouldn't! But when I've got to that point of reasonableness
I'm carried back into vainglory or lunacy or whatever
you may call it by the reflection that things of this kind aren't
primarily dependent on cold logic, or that at least you
can't leave out of the equation the personal sentiment + emotion
which has somehow grown up round me - which I share so
irresistibly. The other night at the Military School Shakir
Beg was talking about patriotism in the army: "Khatun" he
said "we say these things to you because we reckon you as one
of us." And Faisal when I say I'm going home next summer
replies with asperity. "You're not to talk of going home -
your home's here. You may say you're going to see your Father."
Well, you've got very unsatisfactory children! but in spite of
all evidence to the contrary they love you very much.
The airmail goes tomorrow so I must cut short these
unconvincing remarks. Your very devoted daughter Gertrude

Baghdad Oct 17. 1921 Received 10 Nov 1921
Dearest Father. Yesterday, Sunday, I spent an agreeable day.
There
, a young man
who is now Advisor at Ba'qubah called Capt. Reed. He is a very nice boy;
I've known him for a long time. But he has fallen into very solitary habits.
He never comes to see any of us + from his reports I had a feeling that he
was getting rather out of touch. So I telegraphed announcing that I was coming
to lunch with him, hired a motor, + started off on a beautiful sharp
sunshiny morning. I got to Ba'qubah about 11.30 when the sun was
beginning to be pleasantly hot. The place looked charming, buried in its
orange groves, with its sleepy little canal, the tail of the Khurasan,
wandering through the midst of it. I went straight to the Sarai where I
found Capt Reed + his darling old Mutasarrif, Ahmad Halat Beg.
The latter had once called on me but I was out + hadn't yet made
his acquaintance. He is a gentle, courteous old Turkish official of the
best type, conscientious + honest. It was quite delightful to see
the friendly intimacy in between him + Capt Reed. If you asked
one of them a question he turned to the other for confirmation of his
answer. We all three sat in the Mutasarrif's office + talked about
Diyalah affairs for about half an hour, after, which I made my
bow, saying I felt sure he must be busy + that I would wait in
Capt Reed's office till he was ready to go to lunch. But not a bit of
it - the Mutasarrif trotted after us + sat chatting while Capt
Reed signed letters + then insisted on showing me all over
the Sarai, part of which was burnt in last year's disturbances.
And they both bubbled over with a description of the repairs they
intended to make. So I went with Capt Reed to lunch in his
ramshackle little house, wholly, devoid of any vestige of comfort.
The table cloth certainly hadn't been washed for a month.
We lunched off a ragout of sand grouse + a superlatively good melon
famed for its
from Qizil Robat
??
melons and all this time Capt
Reed never stopped talking about his Mutasarrif + his Division.
I was deeply interested but even if I hadn't been I should have
loved to hear him talk, for it was so obviously good for him
to be pouring out his
heart
about all the things that were
nearest to him - his tribes + his shaikhs + Mutasarrif +
how splendidly the latter was doing, how he came out touring the
(P.2 on second sheet)

3 There was a little carpeted diwan tent pitched outside the station
in which the King stood and shook hands with all his subjects. Then
he called in the Cornwallis + me + one or two others + we drank
coffee + talked for a few minutes. Faisal looked very well +
appeared to be very much pleased with the success of his Mosul
visit - thank Heaven he is safe back!
Major Young has arrived, by air form Jerusalem - I saw
him for a moment at the station this morning, and thought him as
conceited + self-sufficient as ever. I've got a dinner of
Cabinet Ministers for him tomorrow night.
Also, Mother, my blue gown + cloak have arrived from
Mrs Bell + unlike Major Young, they are very nice indeed
I am so infinitely grateful for the trouble my kind family
has taken about them. Lennox Gardens papers please copy.
Oct 24 I've had a busy week with nothing particular to show for it. First I
must tell you that Major Young has turned out much nicer than I expected.
I lunched with the Garbetts on the 18th to meet him + had a long +
satisfactory talk with him afterwards. Next night he dined with me.
Mr Cornwallis also came + I had Naji Suwaidi, Sasun Eff., Saiyid
Daud (a cousin of the Naqib's') + 'Abdul Latif Mandil (Basrah, he
is Minister of Commerce) to meet him. Major Young's Arabic is beautiful
+ we had a very pleasant evening. On the 20th we both dined with
the King - a largish party the Slaters, Col. Joyce (just back
with a new wife but she wasn't there that night) Capt Clayton
+ several of the Ministers. Mrs Slater + I sat by Faisal, + as she
can't talk a word of anything the conversation turned mostly to my end
of the table where Naji Suwaidi + I, + Ja'far sitting opposite
to us, carried on with the King a very cheerful talk.
We had all been that afternoon to the races; not that that was
cheerful- it was very hot + boring. But as it was Faisal's
first appearance I beat up Fakhri Jamil + made him come too
by asking him to take me. After which I had to see that he + any
other notables who were there (there were very few) were duly
invited into the King's box for a bit. The ADCs are no good at
their job, but in time perhaps + with lots of pains one will
get it knocked into their heads that a large number of rooted
enmities spring solely from small social negligences.

2.
Division + would even spend the night in an Arab tent - a thing I
don't suppose any Mutasarrif in Turkish times was known to do - + how
he + the people were getting to understand one another in consequence, +
much more besides. After lunch we motored out to Daltawah, about
10 miles N. of Ba'qubah, through charming country covered with scrub,
rather like an English moor except that it was brown + yellow
instead of green + purple. The tails of the Khurasan canal
intersected it, each marked by wavering patches of palm
trees. Daltawah itself, where I had never been before, was
enchanting, a typical little 'Iraq village, set deep in palm
groves + gardens. We called on the Qaimmaqam who is a
friend of mine. Coming unannounced in the early hours of the
afternoon we found him in a garment ressembling a night shirt
but while I went upstairs to see his wife (
the
a Baghdad
girl whom I know well) the Qaimmaqam hastily changed
into a coat + trousers so that when I joined the male
party he was quite respectable. And all the way to Daltawah
+ all the way back, Capt. Reed never stopped talking.
They really are wonderful, these young Englishmen, who are
thrown out into the provinces and left entirely to their own resources.
They so completely identify themselves with their surroundings that
nothing else has any significance for them, but if they think
you're interested they open out like a flower + reveal quite
quite unconsciously, to your amazed eyes wisdom, tact + patience which
you would have thought to be incompatible with their years.
We parted, Capt. Reed + I, with a promise on his side that he
would bring his Mutasarrif to lunch with me next time they
came to Baghdad, + on mine that I would come out soon +
spend a night at Shahraban, where the newly appointed Qaimmaqam
is a Baghdadi whom I like very much.
Today Sidi Faisal returned from Mosul. He arrived at 9 a.m.
+ we all went to the station to welcome him, Sir Percy, Sir Aylmer,
all the Ministers + lots more. It was a very successful little ceremony.
(p. 3 on sheet one )

4.
Most intervals,
of
and a good of time that wasn't intervals, have been
filled up with talking about the future of the Kurds. There are
two respectable old gentlemen here, representatives of a Kurdish
nationalist society in C 'ple, who have come to see if there's
anything to be done in getting an independent Kurdistan set on its feet.
They have spent in all a great many hours with me + while
entertaining the profoundest disbelief, in the prospect of getting wild
Kurdish aghas in wilder mountain country to accept any form
of government, nationalist, or other, I have a warm feeling
of affection for these nice old parties. They dined with me on
the 21st - I had Capt Clayton to meet them + they talked
next day
Kurdish nationalism till, 11 p.m. At 8 a.m. one of them appeared
in my office + presented me with the newly-invented Kurdish
national flag. He also confided to me that he greatly feared
that the other old party, having burnt his boats in C' ple
by coming here, would be forced, if he got no support
from us to place himself at the head of a band of Kurdish
banditti + attack the Turks single hand - "He would,
you see" he sighed, "Have no other alternative." I am persuaded
that the proper alternative for Ri'fat Beg would be a nice
little house in the suburbs, but it wouldn't have been sympathetic
to say so + I therefore murmured such comfort as I could think
of to his colleague.
I've suggested to Sir Percy that it would be a pleasant change
for me to set up as uncrowned Queen of Kurdistan. I don't
want to stand in his way if he has a fancy for the job - we
might perhaps toss for it.
I had tea with Faisal that afternoon to discuss the founding
of a Mesopotamian order (for we must have a decoration of
our own) + we branched off into a long talk about Kurdistan
in which I thought H.M. showed great wisdom. His point
was that it wouldn't suit us or him to burn our fingers
in a Kurdish adventure + that the first thing the Kurds should
be asked to produce was an individual whom they could

5
run for the job of King or president + form a nucleus for the
movement - a Kurdish Faisal in fact.
???
I don't for a
moment believe they have one. I'm persuaded that with
in if time
Kurdistan as with Armenia our armistice declarations
go a great deal further than our capacity to carry them
out, that we must now be careful
with
to make it absolutely
clear that we haven't a penny to spend in furthering
Kurdish independence, for if we encourage people like my
two friends from C' ple we shall only have to abandon them
in the hour of need, which would be the worst thing possible
That's enough about the Kurds, but they'll taken up a
lot of time, for I spent the greater part of one morning in writing
a couple of memorandums about them for Sir Percy + Colin Garbett.
Yesterday, Sunday, I shook myself free + motored out with
Fakhri Eff. to his gardens above Ba'qubah. We started about
8 on a close hot morning - it has been very hot + stuffy
these last few days - + a more beautiful sight I don't
think I ever saw. The dates are late in ripening this year +
are still hanging in great golden crowns on the palms; below
them the pomegranate bushes are weighed down with the
immense rosy globes of their fruit + the orange trees laden
with the pale green + yellow of ripening oranges - it was a
paradise of loveliness; I walked about in a bewilderment
of admiration. There was also a big stretch of vineyard where
the last of the grapes were hanging on the vines - gigantic
bunches of white grapes each sheltered from the sun by a
little roof of liquorice stalks. Our lunch was cooked in
the open air - excellent rice + chicken + stewed meats,
with strained pomegranate juice to drink - + served to us
in an arbour made of a woven roof of boughs. Fakhri's
tenants dropped in to see him + sat round chatting with us
while we lunched - the old man of 80 who had known his
grandfather + all the rest, just as it might have been on a big
estate in England, only that they were much less shy than our

tenants would have been, simpler + better mannered. After lunch
we went on to see the Naqib's sons, Saiyid Safa al Sin
+ Saiyid Muhi al Din, in the house where you + I lunched.
The garden was looking infinitely lovelier than it was
when you + I were there, because of the wealth + beauty
its
of ^ fruit
Saiyid Muhi al Din is rather a difficulty. He is a Turkish
senator, + a Turk, I think, he wants to remain. He retired
to the Diyalah gardens before Faisal came + has never
been back to Baghdad since. I personally like him very much
- he's the best of the Naqib's sons; but he will have to
make up his mind whether he is going to be an 'Iraqi
subject or a Turkish, + if the latter he had best
return to C 'ple.
I've an encouraging feeling that we're getting on. Faisal's
Mosul visit was a great success + has made a very
considerable impression on Baghdad. The Mosulis made a
great deal of him; he has returned delighted with them +
with Mr Nalder + on both sides a feeling of personal
confidence has been established. He is beginning to feel the
worth
of the people we trust + praise, not because we praise
them but because he tests them himself + finds them sterling.
Mr Nalder is one case in point + another is Shaikh 'Ali
Sulaiman of the Dulaim. The latter has been in Baghdad +
has had a heart to heart talk with H.M. in which he
pointed out to him with the blunt good sense which characterises
him, that there are plenty of people who are out to
belittle him because of his refusal to join in last year's
rising, but that his
do
interest is to help in the preservation
of peace + security, + he'll do it for the Arab Govt just as
he did it for the British Govt. Faisal was delightful to him
+ 'Ali, who is one of the great personalities of the 'Iraq,
came away enchanted. Now that's exactly what one
wants to see, the establishment of mutual confidence between

6
the King and his subjects. His charm of manner helps him not a
little + his Quick appreciation a great deal more. Tomorrow
he goes off for a week's tour in the Hillah Division which I
hope will be as fruitful as his visit to Mosul.
Meantime they are getting down to the treaty between the
British + 'Iraq Govts. They had their first conference this
morning, Major Young, Sir Percy + Faisal. Sir Percy told me that
he didn't anticipate any difficulty, + when it is framed it
will be an immense obstacle cleared from our path.
Faisal has been living in terror of it; he is afraid that
the British Govt may ask him to agree to terms which
he can't get his Nationalists to accept, as the French
Govt did in Syria. Till that nightmare has vanished
he has no sense of security. But I don't think he has
reason for anxiety. Sir Percy realizes very well what
divergent elements have to be reconciled, + after all, as
we've seen before, when Sir Percy makes a pronouncement
Mr Churchill has to toe the line. (This paragraph is not
for public use!) We can't afford to give confidence grudgingly.
Faisal has said over + over again that he is powerless
without our help, + he has acted up to his declarations.
There' s no reason to doubt his sincerity (I don't doubt it)
+ we've also got to see his point of view when he says
that if he is entrusted with the responsibility of being
King of the 'Iraq he must be allowed to be a real
King, not the creature of a foreign power, otherwise he is
too heavily handicapped, in a task which at the best
isn't easy.
Oct 27. I went to see Faisal off on the morning of the 25th on Sir Percy's
behalf. All the ministers, several of the Notables, Mr Cornwallis + I were the
party. I breakfasted with Mr Cornwallis afterwards, for we hadn't met
for ever so long + there's somehow never time. The lack of time on my
part is largely because I'm mind- tired + can't get through my

work. I'm thinking of going up to Sulaimani for a few days
next week. Yesterday Sir Percy gave a garden party to meet Major Young.
We asked the Arab ministers + some of the notables - it was the
first time he had had a mixed party of this sort + I think it was
a success. We got the two elements fairly well together. Today
we've had the usual struggle to finish up things for tomorrow' s
airmail - I can't see that I played a worthy part in it. An
American turned up from Tehran. His unlikely name is John
Dos Passos and he's correspondent of the New York Tribune. He
came to tea with me + I found him interesting a pleasant
He has journeyed from Constantinople through the Caucasus + had
plenty of tales to tell.
I've had two delightful sets of letters from you + Mother
- Sep 20 + 28. I'm so grateful to Mother for the trouble she
took about my article - the Fortnightly will do beautifully.
But I'm afraid I shan't be able to write
any
more because I always
sit in Baghdad where there's nothing suitable to write about.
I'm feeling so effete, however, that if there was anything
to write about I couldn't do it. And that's why this long letter
is so dull.
Your very affectionate daughter
Gertrude

Baghdad Oct 31st 1921 Received 9 Dec 1921
Darling Father. I've just received your letters of Oct 12 + 18 by
air mail. As I'm going to Sulaimani on the 2nd I shall leave this to
be sent by the next air mail, in case I don't get back in time to catch
it. Lord! I do need a rest! My brain simply won't work.
As to Hugo's present I've telegraphed that I'll join in. As to
the rose garden, I'm in favour of taking out all the trees, +
always 'as done, but I like your idea of leaving the Irish yews
+ cypresses respectively at the end of the Palm House path +
by the steps. That's that.
Thank you very much indeed for your letters to H. M. +
H.E. They were exactly right + I've no doubt that the
addressees will reply in person. I'm also most grateful
for your inquiries with Garter as to the flag. They have
altered the order of the colours so as to differentiate the
'Iraq flag from the Hijaz. As for the Royal Standard they've
put a big gold crown onto the red triangle, which you
say is all right. It's very effective.
I'm feeling too dull to write letters properly so I'll just give
you a short review of my doings. I gave a dinner party for
Major Young on Friday 28th- a number of my old friends
the Minister of Auqaf
Fakhri Jamil, Abdul Majid Shawi, 'Abdul Jabbar Pasha
Khaujat (one of the leading Christians here) + on top of all
Taufiq Suwaidi, Naji's brother, a clever young lawyer
who has recently come over from Syria. Major Young
was extremely pleasant + we had an interesting +
profitable talk about the future treaty + the need of
making it advantageous to both sides. Taufiq Suwaidi
was streets ahead of the others, quick, intelligent, full
of ideas. Major Young was much impressed by him + by
the contrast he presented with the older lot + I think he
realized, more clearly than he had done before that while
keeping the latter in play, it's the Taufiq Suwaidi kind who

have the push + the drive + therefore must be got to work in
harmony with ourselves.
On Saturday I took Major Young to tea in Saiyid Ja'far's
garden at Kadhimain - where I took you, you remember- +
had some of the Shi'ah merchants of the place to meet him.
It was also quite useful + Saiyid Ja'far was immensely
gratified at our coming .
On Sunday I had a day out. The Dulaim are completing a
big new system of canals, taking off from the Euphrates
above Ramadi + watering the whole desert nearly up to
Baghdad. It's a very fine undertaking the execution of which
has been due mainly to the energy + imagination of
Shaikh 'Ali Sulaiman, backed by Major Yetts. Last time the
latter was in, we arranged that I should come out + see it.
Accordingly, I got hold of Mr Thomson, who is the nicest of
companions + together we set off to Fallujah by motor
about 7 a.m. It takes about 2 hours to motor across to
the Euphrates. At Fallujah we met Major Yetts, stepped
into his car + set off to see the canal. It replaces
a very ancient canal called the Saqlawiyah which
has been for long a danger to Baghdad for it
scoured
has been
dug
deeper + deeper by the current until
unless drastic measures had been taken the whole
Euphrates might easily have turned into it + joined
the Tigris just below Baghdad, flooding the town in
the process. so what they've done is this:
They've put a great head work on the Saqlawiyah where
it takes off from Euphrates + another some 4 miles
lower down where the new system begins, 2 canals to

2 the north of the Saqlawiyah + one (not yet dug) to the south.
The Saqlawiyah itself becomes the drain. We motored to the
second headworks + then all up the northern canal (A)
which is much longer than I've room to show, + then in
between A + B till we came to X where we found a large
- he had motored out to meet us with a pack of shaikhs.
Dulaim camp + lunched in Ali Sulaiman's tent ^ . A +
B will be finished in about 10 days. There are some
1500 tribes men at work. They keep themselves + get no
wage but when the work is done they'll claim their
bit of irrigated land. We motored through what looked
like virgin desert which in a fortnight's time will go
under the plough. It wasn't however, really virgin; if you
looked closely you saw the track of ancient canals though they
were almost obliterated; moreover almost always where a mound
rises above the level of the plain it yields ancient bricks. So it is
that industrious cultivators of Abbasid times save their descendants
expense + labour by providing them with building materials for
the headworks of their new canals. We could not go very much
further by motor for a great length of the central canal
had been used for irrigation last year + all the ground
near it was tilled. We headed however for some tents
+ there got a couple of Arab ponies + a guide to take us
in to Nuqtah, half way on the Baghdad-Fallujah
road. We rode as fast as the broken ground, + also the
broken saddlery would allow. My saddle held out bravely
+ I even had a bridle, but I didn't use it for my
pony was accustomed to nothing but a halter + jibbed
at the harsh bit. Mr Thomson was less fortunate; his
stirrup leathers gave way at an early stage, so did the
bit of string that served as a bridle + his pony didn't go as
gently in its halter as mine. Nevertheless it was a wonderful
two hours' ride. The country was alive with tents + flocks
the early barley, sown for fodder, was thinly green, the
fish lept in the canals as we spashed through them + the

were
people ^ wandering in to their tent villages, here a camel or
two stalking along the canal bank, there a few cows or a
little flock of sheep, + the evening meal a-cooking by the
black booths. The sun set as we reached Nuqtah, + having given
our guide enough + to spare to provide himself + the ponies
with a night's food + lodging, we got into our motor, duly
waiting for us, + came contentedly home.
Nov 1
Faisal came back from his Hillah tour on Monday. He has
been to Karbala, Najaf, Diwaniyah + Rumaithah + seems
to have had a triumphal progress. I think the provinces are
beginning to wake up to the fact that they really have got
an Arab King, + that it's something to be proud of. The
tribes come in by the thousand horse to bid him welcome
+ they say that in Karbala his progress to the shrine surpassed
everything of the kind that the town has seen, even the
famous visit of Naszud Din Shah of Persia. I haven't
however heard his own account of it, for I've been both tired +
preliminary
busy + he also is preoccupied with the ^ negotiations with Sir
Percy + Major Young over the treaty, in which I have no
part. Also I fancy he is very much taken up by Haddad
Pasha who arrived by air on Sunday + I hope will
depart by air or otherwise at the earliest possible date.
For he's a busybody of the first water - he came to see
me on Monday morning, a pleasant garrulous old man
with whom I should have enjoyed conversing if I hadn't
been acutely concious that he regards himself as peripatetic
advisor to the British Govt (+ everyone else) on all
Arab questions + that he'll offer advice as gaily about
Mesopotamia after a 12 hours' acquaintance with it as he
would about his own Syrian country. I've managed to
wriggle out of a second appointment with him+ I've a
pious hope that when I come back from Sulaimani he
may be gone - it certainly won't be Sir Percy's fault if
he isn't! He talks admirable English, having lived
some 30 years in Egypt; he was Director of Public

3 security in Damascus under Faisal + followed him in exile
to Europe where he was very useful in helping to put up the
Syrian case. But for all that he's the veriest, old windbag
+ we've got enough of his sort without importing more.
There was another big dinner party last night at the
Military School which I should have enjoyed very much
if I hadn't been so tired. Mrs Joyce + Mrs Slater were
there + two other women whose husbands have jobs
in the Arab army; Ja'far + Nuri,
why
by whom I
sat + a number of Arab guests, including Haji
Naji. It was extremely pleasant + friendly. But I do
wish (this is highly confidential) that our women would
show some sense of suitability in their attire.
Mrs Slater
came in a brilliant green + gold gown, cut outrageously
low, with no sleeves at all, + this in a party
which included a number of respectable old Sayids
and magnates whose conception of female attire is
that it should leave no female visible. Isn't it
incredible that our women shouldn't realize what they must
look like to eyes thus trained! I can do nothing but
curse in private to Sir Percy who heartily echoes my oaths
(Lady Cox, I needn't say, is a model of discretion + backed
me when I issued a request - in her name - that
the women who came to the Municipal Dinner in July
should wear high gowns.) I hope that Sir Percy, the first
time he himself, goes to one of these functions, will send out
a sumptuary order, but I had to beg him not to do it on
my report - I don't want to antagonize the whole feminine
world, with which I stand badly enough already. Im
grossen und ganzen damn women!
Today the post brought letters from you + Mother dated
Oct 6 - I suppose you'll write henceforward by air mail.
Your account of my finances isn't over satisfactory, bless

you for it all the same. What an excessive amount of
trouble you take about your children + we accept it all
as a matter of course + more shame to us. At any rate
I do realize from time to time what it is to have
someone always watching + caring for one, without the
care having any relation to the worth of the object it's
expended on. The object is worth less than you can
guess. I think I may have been of some use here but I
suspect I've come very near the end of it.
But at least I'm your endlessly loving daughter
Gertrude.
This is to Mother: never mind about the frames
for my diamonds- it's just like that stupid
Marie not to know where they were. I can't for
the life of me remember the necklace you so very
kindly offer me as a fender, but far be it from
me to refuse any generosity! At the same time
like to
don't let me ave anything you ^ wear yourself.
I daresay the Arabs won't mind if I don't put
any diamonds in my hair

Baghdad Oct 13 1921
Received Oct 25th 1921 By Airmail
Dearest Mother. I was so very glad to get your
letter of Sep 6 with the description of Frances + her
family, + to hear of your pleasure in the
engagement. The only sad thing is their going off
to S. Africa. I do regret it very much for your
sake + Father's + yet I feel with them in wanting
to go back to the place where Hugo has worked so
many years. The world is still too big, isn't it.
To come to less vital concerns, I was deeply
interested in what you say about the new
gardener. All your schemes about the garden
sound very nice + when once we've made up our
minds to the absence of Hanagan, bless him, what a
comfort it will be to have someone capable +
energetic with ideas of his own + eager to
carry them out. I am so glad you like him.
I wonder if you will be able to write by
airmail - it would mean that we should
have each other's answers in under a
month which does make a great deal of
difference. I forget what I've written about
before I get your reply.
A nice Judicial man has come out to replace
Sir Edgar Bonham Carter,
names
Davidson - he has

been having tea with me today. His wife comes next
month + I do hope she'll be nice too + that she will be
friends with me. With Aurelia Tod away - + I'm
afraid she is not coming back this winter- I'm left
without any female I can trouble to be intimate
with + it's a very great drawback. Mrs Slater (whom
Father met in Egypt) is both nice + intelligent but
she is entirely taken up, not by Mr Slater, but
by the officer in command of the Air Force- a
dull little man, I think, but she doesn't seem to
find him so! Mrs Garbett is a sort of little
Undine, very attractive, but not at all human
+ there's really no one else of any interest.
When I feel lonely, I find myself riding off to
spend an hour with Haji Naji, an odd
substitute for a female friend, but the best I
can find.
I wish Milly or Sarah or someone of
that kind were married to a Mesopotamian
husband! Janet Courtney, now - someone
you could have a good talk to (That's partly
why I talk so much in my letters!)
Ever your very affectionate daughter
Gertrude
